Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 8 hours
3-5 hours.
5-6 hours

The number of required readings was incredibly overwhelming, so I just stopped reading them. 
0-1 hrs most weeks. 3-5 hrs on weeks with problem sets or essays.
4-5 sometimes more depending on papers.
It depended on the assignment, but anywhere from 2-6
3-5 hours per week outside the classroom
10 hours per week
1-2 hours on weeks where we had a problem set, 2-3 hours on weeks when we had an essay
Practically, I spent about 6 hours per week on this course, but had I done all of the readings it would have been 10-15 hours.
1-5 hours depending on the assignment given

Strengths : diversity of topics covered in the health systems domain 

Weakness : Lack of quantitative coursework like using software models

Strengths:
Being from a non-health background, the course gave a good start to a potential career in global health.

I strongly feel that this course, as a requirement for the global health concentration, could use significant restructuring and updating. 
It should be more focused on skill acquisition to help inform our future work, and less on theoretical concepts.

This course was a complete waste of time.  Having completed the course, I am still unsure of a single learning objective we were supposed to get out of it.  All we did was talk about a different country's health system each week.  There was never any instruction on key concepts we were supposed to learn or any skills we were supposed to acquire.  We just talked about different health systems each week.  The homework required at most a high school level of thinking, requiring little to zero critical thought.  I'm sad I wasted time taking this class.  I did not learn a single thing.

I was disappointed in this course. There was a ton of work for little reward. The days where we analyzed specific health systems were valuable, but a lot of the course was spent on more vague concepts and we didn't get in to as much detail on them. I enjoyed the modeling but would have rather it been much more detailed than the basic reviews we did.

The course covers very interesting and unique material and Prof Hecht has the experience to really give powerful real world expertise in the class. However there are a few areas that need improvement. Many times it felt that we never really were able to "dig" into the material at a high level, or get past a surface analysis of readings due to the way that the class was set up. An excessive amount of time was spent on student presentations, and during Q/As several students would consistently dominate them and provide lengthy comments that prevented the class from moving forward. Many of the students did not seem to prepare very well for the class, thus when we broke into groups it was challenging to have a meaningful conversation or come to a consensus. The class would benefit from capped enrollment, as this would allow the students to engage more meaningfully with the material and work better in groups. However I think the most important feedback is that Hecht needs to lecture more and provide his insight and analysis on the material--it is much more productive to hear from him rather than other students in the class.
Good course- the material presented is interesting, and the use of guest speakers really improved the quality of the class.

On paper, the course laid out some great learning objectives.  However, the lectures were mismanaged and we spent too much time each week on portions of the lecture that were meant to introduce a topic or take 20 minutes at the most.  I would have liked to learn more applied technical skills related to health system reform modeling and evaluation.  Instead, I feel like I learned more about what the skills are by name but not how to do them.

This was the worst course I have ever had the displeasure of taking. We are talking I would have rather cut off a toe than taken this course. It was universally hated by everyone who took it this semester. 
Strengths: None
Weaknesses: the reading load (somewhere between 100-300 pages a week), the weekly reports (if I wanted to regurgitate information to someone I would have stayed as an undergrad), the student presentations (they take up 60% of class time and if I wanted to hear my fellow students talk I would invite them for drinks), and the instructor (old white guy with a savior complex who thinks he can do no wrong and refuses to take criticism). 

I cannot stress enough how bad this course is. My recommendation would be to just throw the whole thing away.

This lecture was poorly organized during class time. Each week we would meet and the first half an hour would be spent on what we did last week and what we should be talking about this week. This in turn set every lecture behind. The student presentations often mirrored the readings and the weekly assignments, making them almost redundant in material, especially when there was a writing assignment on the same week. There was a lot of almost hostile comments made by the professor about our work ethic, timing on the presentations, and constant reminder of the no laptop policy. The two weeks that a guest lecturer spoke were the highlight of this course -- it actually seemed like they wanted to share their real world experience and insight rather than copying one lecture slide given in a foreign language and trying to apply it to this course. Overal, if this was not a requirement of the global health concentration, I would have dropped it.

The professor has accomplished a lot and has been a part of some really amazing global public health work over the years. Unfortunately, the class was very disorganized, which led to us running behind schedule, being unclear on what homework or problem sets were being assigned, and how to best prep for class activity. There should be less emphasis on student presentations (of which we would often spend 45 minutes of the class time on) and more emphasis on lecture and group activities. The best lectures were pulled from the professor's work with Pharos Consulting, because it allowed us to interact with very relevant and current topic areas.

strengths: learning about different country's health systems
weaknesses: way too much readings. there were about 10-12 readings per week with about half of them 50-200 pages each. The amount of the readings discouraged many people from even doing any of them. Also, the student presentations were ineffective. They should've been time limited and kept to only one presentation per class. There were times when the presentations took more than half the class. Everyone was zoned out. We are not paying $40,00 per year to listen to students, the professor should be doing most of the teaching.

Strengths: guest speakers (e.g. Gavin Yamey)

Weaknesses: 
- having student presentations every week
- class is too large to accommodate the goals for the class, as a result, was not engaging
- difficult to learn and apply the skills presented, because they were presented very minimally through doing the homework
- difficult to apply to paper

I'm still not sure what the point of this course was. We never actually learned anything valuable/important about health systems and instead just ended up learning random facts about health systems around the world. There was no foundation set to actually analyze health systems and what could be done to improve them.
Not enough instructor engagement

The course could be improved by having more structured lesson plans, focusing more on technical skills. This course is listed as a credit for my modelling concentration, but I don't feel like my modelling skills have been sufficiently enhanced after taking the course. The discussions were great though, and the guest speakers were phenomenal!

Overall, I can definitely speak more knowledgeably on Global Health Systems and subsequently have a decent understanding of the financing mechanisms health systems around the world implement. This course was beneficial in that respect, but ultimately did not fulfill anywhere near the potential it could have reached for several reasons: 

1) Class Student Presentations 

Sometimes 30-40 minutes of the 1 hour 50 minute class would be allocated to student presentations, which were essentially just a summary of the readings. Whilst I appreciate that public speaking and presentation skills are important to learn, thats not what Im paying $60k per year for and having to sit through some pretty bad presentations attempting to summarize things we were meant to have read was painful, and frankly insulting to the intelligence of many of the students. 

2) Group work and Class Debates

I appreciated the intent and attempt to have debates and group work but ultimately the execution was poor. Firstly, 47 College classroom is just not setup sufficiently well to have effective group work for a class of this size with like 45 people. The result was about 3 people contributing and everyone else sitting around who may as well not have been there, maybe I had a bad group. The debates were basically 2 minute snippets from each group but it wasnt really a proper debate. This would be done much better by dedicating a whole class to a debate activity and smaller groups could have 15 mins each to debate a topic in teams in front of the class.

3) Assignments

Found the essay prompts pretty good and provoked some decent analysis. Some other assignments were ok, some were literally regurgitating info that required no critical thinking and to be honest was painful.


4) Watching YouTube lectures in class 

A few minute videos are fine but really.... a 20 minute lecture from the Thailand Health minister shown in class was just awful. Firstly, it could have been assigned pre-class. Secondly, his accent was difficult to understand and the quality of the audio was abysmal. 20 minutes of my life Im not getting back.

5) Technology Issues 

On more than one occasion with guest lecturers via video we had technology issues.  In one case 20+ minutes of class time was wasted, which when you only have 1 lecture a week is pretty embarrassing for Yale and a waste of our time. Guest lecturers were very good though.

6) Readings 

Some weeks it was 300+ pages. Assigning massive reports to read just not helpful and nor is it realistic to just skim reports like this without any direction. If allocating readings like this then at least prioritize them. A lot of the readings were also super old and the global health field has evolved massively so this old material is just not as relevant anymore. 

All of this highlights that the Professor did very little actual teaching or lecturing throughout this entire semester, which is a shame because he is clearly a very knowledgeable and influential figure in this field who as a lot of experience and wisdom that could have been imparted on students.

Gives exposure to a wide range of topics.
The readings could be improved. They were mostly boring and we were able to find more helpful and interesting journal articles online.
Focus could also be given to imbibing certain quantitative/technical skill (such as LiST, Spectrum)
This is a course with potential but the professor should be replaced or monitored extensively by the administration with a very short leash.

I enjoyed this course. I was looking forward to it, as the MPH Global Health Concentration capstone, and felt like I gained a lot of what I was looking for. The guest speakers were of very high caliber. One piece of feedback is that I wish student presentations had been shorter and there had been more group work time. I also did not find the weekly assignments very helpful and found that they took a lot of time.

Strengths: 
+ The structure of the class flows well and is nicely split between learning the fundamentals, assessing UHC reforms, and assessing scale-up programs
+ The TAs were great and responded quickly with feedback
+ The outside presenters were always phenomenal

Weaknesses:
- The number of required readings was overwhelming, so I stopped reading. Didn't affect my class performance.
- The student presentations were designed to take up no more than 20 minutes of class with each presentation lasting 8 minutes. Often times, presentations went WAAYYY over the designated amount of time and took up a significant portion of the class. One particular presentation took 20-25 minutes itself. The presentations often times did not cover new information that was not introduced in the readings, so when I did do the readings, it felt very repetitive. I didn't come to class to be re-taught information I've read by my peers. 
- Several problematic comments referring to African nations and their development were said that the professor declined to comment on or made himself e.g., "I can't believe this [African capital city] looks so urban!" or "People in Africa who can't afford healthcare have to barter for services with potatoes and woven rugs." Often times I felt as if the professor took on a white savior complex when he described low- and middle-income African and Asian countries.

This class has the potential to be fantastic, given that Professor Hecht has a LOT of experience and is very knowledgable. However, I felt like there was TOO many class presentations and videos/group work that took up time that I would have rather spend learning from Professor Hecht. The presentations/videos were redundant from the readings and problem sets, and I rather have had more actual lecture time.

The topics in this course were engaging and provided great opportunity for learning and discussion. The format of the class could be improved to better facilitate this learning. The size of the course was a big challenge and it would have been better to limit the number of student presentations to leave more time for discussion and presentations by guest speakers. The best class sessions were the ones in which experts spoke about their work and first hand experiences.

Strengths: The class has a lot of breadth to it and we had fantastic guest speakers! It was also cool that we had a modeling workshop
Weaknesses: We always seemed to run out of time, and the teacher didn't always seem as interested in the input of others. It just wasn't always organized.
Weekly assignments and their design are major strengths. Readings could have been better selected and then discussed more directly at class that week.

STRENGTHS
-- The group presentations were a great way to collaborate with classmates and dig deeper into specific topics. Projects like these create memories in students minds that last longer than memories of lectures past.
-- The class periods were well-structured, dynamic, and engaging. Classes often opened with brief videos, then incorporated full-class discussions, lectures from the professor, student presentations, small and large group discussions and debates, and guest lectures. I appreciated the planning and effort it took to put together these classes, and the end result. 
-- I appreciated the opportunities to do group work with classmates. These were important moments for us to engage with the material to strengthen our understanding.
-- The assignments were interesting and the essay prompts were the right balance of general and specific; essay prompts should be open-ended questions like these were, that give students the chance to think through problems on their own. 
-- The PowerPoints were well-organized, and the content of the course was relevant and interesting. 

WEAKNESSES
-- Assignments should be written up and posted on Canvas at least 2 weeks before the deadline. Students have complicated schedules, and time management is smoother when we can prepare more in advance. Alternatively, halve the amount of work required for each assignment. 
-- The most helpful way to organize course readings on Canvas is in a File, which can be downloaded in its entirety, and then easily accessed when offline or facing slow internet access. Modules and links to external websites are difficult to navigate. It is easier to download all the files for each class in one go, and that is best done when they are all included in a folder in Files.

I was really disappointed in this course. Perhaps that's harsh, but it was the class I was most looking forward to this semester. The topic is so interesting, and the professor's background meant that he could add a lot of his personal experiences to the mix. Unfortunately, I think that the class was just poorly organized and too big for what the professor wanted. At that class size, I would have much preferred a more standard lecture format to the large group discussions. Splitting the class into four large groups did not work. The desks were not arranged for that, and inevitably students on the periphery of the group did not have a chance to participate. Smaller groups of three or four would have worked better. The problem sets were good, but the essay questions often involved too many questions. In attempting to answer all of the questions, the style and structure of the essay itself was often compromised. The presentations and final essays were useful assignments as well.

strengths: gives a broad picture of how the PH works actually is implemented in LMIC and what a donor's perspective can be regarding any specific issue in global health
weakness: cannot fit many topics in detail (but there are other detailed courses separately available)

The course was a good platform for continuing to think about and develop perspectives in global health policy and health finance. However, the time breakdowns for the class schedule were rarely adhered to with student presentations taking longer than anticipated.

This course was overwhelming. I do not think our professor used class time appropriately and the course seemed very disorganized. He assigned a ridiculous amount of readings that were just not possible to complete in one week. Overall I did not enjoy this class

Strengths: good understanding of international health systems that I didn't know before. Appreciated the in-depth knowledge of specific countries. 

Weaknesses: the group discussions in class were not productive, way too large of groups.
Overall decent, interesting topics but a lot of tedious work. Slow feedback on projects and assignments.

Strengths:
The course allows for a more nuanced look at how financing decisions are made pertaining to interventions as well as their impact on global health
Teaching about different models with respect to a countries needs, population, and financial situations is imperative for work in global health as well as allows for a more educated criticism of the US health system (for future reform efforts)

Weaknesses: 
The course often appeared disorganized and there was some criticism about what the course taught, however, I found the teachings to be quite helpful and the student presentations presented a great opportunity to understand a subject of one's choice in more detail.

Towards the end (last ~4 weeks) this course improved drastically, however it should be noted this was in part due to outside lecturers. I believe the instructor had the best intentions and applied himself to teaching, but I felt that often the blanket statements/general concepts applied were fairly intuitive and didn't signal any particularly in-depth knowledge of the (admittedly many) countries we looked at.

Robert has a lot of interesting anecdotes and a lot of global health experience. However, this class was really frustrating because it felt like each week we always got stuck on a particular topic and the class never moved forward. Students were regurgitating the same talking points and giving a lot of comments without moving forward the conversation. Instead of guiding the lecture and discussions I think Robert got caught into this as well. I don't think we ever got through everything that Robert outlined at the beginning of the lecture. I would recommend getting rid of the group work altogether and focusing on the lectures and Robert's case studies. The paired presentations were also just on the weekly readings and I don't think were necessary; they just ate up a lot of time.
I enjoyed the topics of the course, but wish there could have been more discussion. I felt that time was not always used effectively to truly dive into topics.

Strengths: This class provided a nice opportunity to explore topics that I'm really interested in. The country case studies of UHC reform efforts were very interesting to read and write about, and the final paper was actually one of my favorite assignments at YSPH so far, thanks in large part to the flexibility around the topic and the support of the TAs.

Weaknesses: While the topics we studied were really interesting, class time was poorly structured and often felt like it added little to my learning. The student presentations often just recap the readings and add little new insight or information, and given the large number of students who had to be accommodated in the presentations, I did not find the worth the time they consumed. The videos and discussions were often too loosely-structured to to deepen learning or challenge assumptions. Dividing us into country groups for in-class debates was a nice attempt at more interactive learning, but I didn't feel like we had adequate time to prepare for these discussions, so it ended up feeling like a distraction.

In general, I think that this class has a lot of potential, but in its current format, it tries to accomplish too much, reducing the overall quality of the class.

Professor is really knowledgeable, topics are really interesting; expected more quantitative use of data and analysis which was what the class was originally pitched as. Lack clear grading schemes for assignments and presentations.

Strengths : vast experience in the field of health which brought interesting insights in the class discussions and coursework 

Weaknesses : we never managed to finish the agenda of the class as too much was packed into one class or the pace wasn't managed very well

Strengths:
Hes very resourceful, knowledgable and gave us information about all his current projects. We had a opportunity to hear from several great minds in that field like Gavin Yamey, over a video call or in person. And the initiative of a workshop on LiST was also a highlight.

Prof Hecht is kind and well-intentioned, but is very clearly not a professional professor. 
He failed to stay on task and accomplish everything that is on the agenda, and instead would talk extensively about personal work experiences for the majority of the course. 
Additionally, I think the professor of this course should be more sensitive to cultural humility.

Robert Hecht was one of the most arrogant people I have ever met.  He relied on student presentations to take up most of the class time or invited outside speakers to talk.  He lectured for very little of the class time.  When he did lecture he mostly would just talk about wherever he had just come from for whatever reason.  We get it, you travel for work.  One time he presented slides in French because "he didn't have time to translate them."  The slides were from 2014.  We get it, you speak French.  Robert was a very lackluster professor even in a school where lackluster teaching is to be expected.
Professor Hecht is clearly very knowledgeable about the subject matter, but seems more focused on his research than the class.

Hecht is very knowledgable and clearly has great expertise and experience in this field. However I wished that he lectured more and presented more of his own take and high level analysis on the content at hand. I felt that lectures were frequently summaries of the readings' findings, which is not very productive if one has already read and analyzed the readings.

Very interesting Professor who has clearly accomplished a great deal throughout his career. I do wish that he spent more time teaching content to us in class, as some discussions were harder to engage in when we did not review topics/material together.

TERRIBLE
If I wanted to here an old white guy with a savior complex talk for 50 minutes I would tune into FOX News. Yale would have fewer problems with the course if it was taught by a cantaloupe.
Professor Hecht spent more time discussing how far behind we were than he did teaching us new material.
Occasionally gets off track with lecturing; there never seems to  be enough time in the class
Talked way too much. He should try to be more concise with his words. The things he said could've been said in a few minutes but he elongated his messages which caused many people to zone out.
I've heard he does better in smaller class settings. The class needs to be redesigned.

Robert was hostile, made blanket statements that were offensive and often racist/misogynistic. I only went to class because attendance was mandatory and every minute spent in class was a waste of my time.

Professor Hecht is a very pleasant man and I enjoyed chatting with him before and after class. Unfortunately, as a Professor he just disappointed me in comparison to the benchmark set by other Professors at YSPH. I think he is overextended in his non-Yale commitments with Pharos and the traveling associated with that, which leaves him not putting his Yale work as a priority and delivering a class that is well beneath the quality that he is capable of if he actually put some effort in to teaching rather than creating lessons that are packed with what I would call filler.

He is great. Very charismatic.
But chose TAs that were tardy. We did not get our PSET results on time. For instance, we had not received our evaluation of Essay 2 by the time we had to submit essay 3. Their evaluations could have helped in improving our Essay 3.

Professor Hecht is using his position at Yale to market Pharos.  He shows up to class unprepared (sometimes skipping it entirely), plays YouTube videos, delegates teaching responsibilities to students and encourages student infighting by being out of touch with the course material and applying different standards of evaluation to different students depending upon whether he likes the student or not.

Professor Hecht was excellent. He is incredibly knowledgeable on the global health field, and one of my favorite parts of the course was hearing about his firsthand experiences working with Pharos, at WHO, etc.

Strengths:
+ Has profound knowledge on LMIC health system development
+ Really enjoyed when Professor Hecht presented on his current work to demonstrate a tangible example of the material that we're learning

Weaknesses:
- I understand that Professor Hecht is very busy, but he often came off as inaccessible
- Professor Hecht and other students have made said problematic statements in class. Often times, I felt Professor Hecht took on a white savior complex when referring to low- and middle-income countries, particularly those in Africa. He has made very sweeping statements like "people in Africa who can't afford healthcare have to barter for services with potatoes and woven rugs." Other students have made problematic statements that he failed to address in class, like "I can't believe that this [African capital city] looks so urban!". (What else is it supposed to look like--dirt roads and mud huts?) I would say as the class went on, fewer of these comments were made, but I felt uneasy going to class after the first few weeks.
He has a lot of experience and is very smart, but needs to spend more time actually lecturing the students rather than letting students do the lecturing.

Strengths: Very knowledgeable and personable one-on-one
Weaknesses: Sometimes a bit dismissive and time wasn't always kept well.
Dr. Hecht's direct experience in the world of global health is a major asset of this course. When he drew from his own presentations / work, those were the best parts of class.

STRENGTHS
-- The professor appeared to have put considerable effort and care into crafting lesson plans, with many different ways of engaging students. The professor found exciting ways to approach topics from several angles.
-- Hecht brought in examples of analyses of global health system reforms not just from real life, but also from his own recent work. When a professor sets out a narrative like that, it is often far more compelling for the listeners than a Fact. Fact. Fact. kind of lecture devoid of the good parts and the real life urgency of problem-solving and saving lives.

WEAKNESSES
-- The professor rightly asked that students respect his time and avoid using phones and laptops during class, arriving late, etc. However, it is better to mention these classroom standards all at once at the start or middle or end of each lecture, rather than as an immediate response to an individual student using their laptop or arriving late. Those of us who abide by standards will do so without many reminders, and those who dont will probably ignore tactics like that anyway. Best not to call out individuals that way.
excellent!

Dr. Hecht has a lot of expertise in the subject matter and demonstrated it through his anecdotes and presentations, however he would sometimes spend too much time on a specific, causing students to tune out. Perhaps being more succinct and hitting the main ideas would be more beneficial.
Appreciated his real-world knowledge. Felt like he had a difficult time establishing good class conduct- too much cell phones among students and they didn't really contribute.
Nice and very intelligent
In future I would recommend utilising his broad rolodex to bring in individual experts on different areas we are looking at.
Robert was really nice and had a lot of interesting stories from his travels. I just wished that was the focus of the course.
Very Knowledgeable, was able to give valuable examples from his work

More can be gained from the professor sharing his experiences and opinions on the topics instead of opening it up to the class to answer. The class is well structured but a lot of what the professor wants to achieve in class does not get covered because of poor time management and time wasted going over the logistics.

problematic statements that students shared were not corrected by instructor, instructor did not help me learn anything that will equip me with tools to work in reforming health systems which is why i took the class. i heard that this professor has a group of undergraduates who are on a team consulting for the global fund. i wish he did that for MPH students instead as i see myself in that line of work after graduation. i wish lectures were actually taught by the professor with presentation slideshows and actual notes i can take away. the student presentations were not helpful as they were not experts in the given topic. i wish the professor had prepared for the class more. he also said rude things to students and to myself as i was giving my presentation. my presentation was cut short to 10 minutes because the professor hustled us that day, whereas other students were given up to 40 or 50 minutes at times. i was unfairly judged on my presentation because he was in a bad mood and technology was not working that day.
It's a good course. Covers many country case studies. There is a lot to learn. Iittle too theoretical and less practical sometimes.

Definitely take the course if you want to learn about decisions surrounding health systems in the lower-middle income countries. However, keep in mind that the workload is quite a bit so be prepared for that.
I would not recommend taking this course unless it was to complete a requirement for the global health concentration.

I would not recommend this class to anyone.  The only reason I took it was because it's a requirement for the global health concentration.  Clearly nobody reads the reviews because the class had horrible reviews before I took it and all of the complaints in the reviews were still present in the class.  You will learn nothing in this class.  A colossal waste of time.
It is an interesting course that has a lot of potential--I would recommend the class if the professor implements the types of reforms that I detailed in the section above.
Good course for anyone who wants to learn more about how to evaluate a country's progress in achieving UHC or other health reforms.

Summary: Clusterfuck
I would sooner recommend a swim in the New Haven Sewer treatment plant.
Not worth it, unless you've got a background in health systems.
Only take it if it's a requirement. If not, then take a Jackson or other course that will teach you about health systems much better.
I do not recommend this course to another student.
I would not recommend this class to any student.
If a student was interested in learning about health systems in LMICs in a general sense then I would recommend. However, if technical skills are sought after, I would not.

I am unsure if I can recommend this course for the reasons outlined above. If major changes were made then yes, but it appears that similar feedback was given last year but many students still appeared dissatisfied with the course this year, which is a shame.
The prof comes off as very interesting but his suggested readings are rather dry. Would recommend only if you are especially interested.
Do not take this course until the administration has had an opportunity to replace the professor or has made a commitment to supervising the next iteration of this course.

Strengths: 
+ The structure of the class flows well and is nicely split between learning the fundamentals, assessing UHC reforms, and assessing scale-up programs
+ The TAs were great and responded quickly with feedback
+ The outside presenters were always phenomenal

Weaknesses:
- The number of required readings was overwhelming, so I stopped doing the readings. Didn't affect my class performance.
- The student presentations took up way too much class time and presented on information that we were already assigned to read. 
- Several problematic comments referring to African nations and their development were said that the professor declined to comment on or made himself. Often times I felt as if the professor took on a white savior complex when he described low- and middle-income African and Asian countries. He could use fewer sweeping statements when referring to the development status of these countries.
There needs to be major formatting changes for this class, but the content is good.
A class about financing, universal health coverage, and other world development issues. The class has potential, but as is I would not recommend it.
This course gives you the practical skills and case studies to evaluate and read about program scale-ups and UHC reform in LMIC.
I would recommend this course as a good introduction to concepts of global health, and how to apply them practically to inform public health decision-making tailored to each situation.
I would not recommend this course despite the interesting subject matter because the class was poorly organized and frustrating.
highly recommended, and probably the only course that will give you first hand experience sharing of global health works in LMIC

A decent course for continuing global health discourse at YSPH, however it is difficult to tangibly identify specific skill sets or learning objectives which are clearly obtained over the semester - lots of breadth, with little depth it felt.
I would not recommend. I don't feel the course has lived up to any expectations it holds
If you are interested in learning about international health systems, this is a great course. If
A lot of work and needs a little bit more organization.

I really liked this course as a foundation for understanding global health . The course allows for a more nuanced look at how financing decisions are made pertaining to interventions as well as their impact on global health. In addition, teaching about different models with respect to a countries needs, population, and financial situations is imperative for work in global health as well as allows for a more educated criticism of the US health system (for future reform efforts)
I think this course needs a little more structure to be classified as the capstone course for the global health concentration. I would recommend it if more discussion was incorporated.
In its current form, I would not recommend this class. But I'm hopeful that it will improve, and think that these topics are essential learning for all YSPH students!
Good as an introductory class to global health systems, doable by students who do not have a strong public health background.
i would not recommend this class because i came out with no tangible skills in global health / reforming health systems
